poem:
The Price of Emission  

The coal dust clings,   
unseen shackles of trade,  
oceans whisper of swollen tides,  
skies wear a cloak of blame.  

Numbers dance like ghosts,  
etching worth in wilted leaves,  
the billowing weight—  
900 billion sighs;  

yet still the engine hums,  
echoing the price of breath.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Cost of emissions from five major Australian resource companies more than $900bn, study finds Five of Australia’s biggest fossil fuel producers could be on the hook for hundreds of billions of dollars in damages after a US research team developed a method to link individual companies to specific climate harms and put a dollar figure to the impact. This is the result of a new peer-review study published in the journal Nature that sought to". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
